thig1.11:1.2: The commentary explains that the first two things make you crooked: (_khujjakaraṇahetutāya tadubhayaṁ “khujja”nti vuttaṁ_), while the husband *is* crooked (a hunchback). This may be so, but I think it is a double entendre.
thig1.11:1.3: The mortar and pestle feature prominently in the sexual imagery of Rig Veda 1.29, where the kitchen implements are analogized with the pressing of soma on the altar. Both _musala_ and “pestle” derive from roots “to pound”.
